qas.question: What is the code for separating lines?
What is the code for separating paragraphs?
How is newline normalization accomplished in Mac OS X?
How does the newliine normallization format work?

answers.text: every possible newline character is converted internally to a common newline

plausible_answers.text: U+2028 LINE SEPARATOR and U+2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR

qas.question: What widely adopted solution did Unicode provide?

plausible_answers.text: it is an internal operation just for rendering

qas.question: Why does it matter which newline character is chosen?
What is the name of the Cocoa text system?
What are common newlines converted into?

context: In terms of the newline, Unicode introduced <a0_0><b4_0>U+2028<a0_0/> LINE SEPARATOR and <a1_0>U+2029<a1_0/> PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR<b4_0/>. This was an attempt to provide a Unicode solution to encoding paragraphs and lines semantically, potentially replacing all of the various platform solutions. In doing so, Unicode does provide a way around the historical platform dependent solutions. Nonetheless, few if any Unicode solutions have adopted these Unicode line and paragraph separators as the sole canonical line ending characters. However, a common approach to solving this issue is through newline normalization. This is achieved with the <a2_0>Cocoa text system<a2_0/> in <b5_0>Mac OS X<b5_0/> and also with <b7_0>W3C XML<b7_0/> and HTML recommendations. In this approach <a3_0><b8_0>every possible newline character<b8_0/> is converted internally to a common newline<a3_0/> (which one does not really matter since <b6_0>it is an internal operation just for rendering<b6_0/>). In other words, the text system can correctly treat the character as a newline, regardless of the input's actual encoding.
